message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's symptoms suggest a serum sickness-like reaction, which is a delayed hypersensitivity reaction to the antivenom. The next best step in patient management is a glucocorticoid taper with antihistamines to alleviate symptoms. NSAIDs are not indicated for this type of reaction, and plasmapheresis is not typically used for serum sickness-like reactions.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest serum sickness, a type III hypersensitivity reaction which can occur after treatment with antivenom. Glucocorticoids and antihistamines are the standard treatment for serum sickness. NSAIDs can worsen the rash and plasmapheresis is not indicated for this type of reaction. Therefore, (A) is the next best step in patient management.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient is showing signs of serum sickness, an immune complex reaction to the foreign protein in the antivenom. Treatment options include glucocorticoids and antihistamines, with a tapering dose over several days. NSAIDs may be used for symptom relief but do not address the underlying immune reaction. Plasmapheresis is not a first-line treatment for serum sickness.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient is experiencing a serum sickness-like reaction to the sheep hyperimmune Fab antivenom, which is an immune complex reaction mediated by IgG antibodies. The treatment is a glucocorticoid taper with antihistamines. Antihistamines alone won’t be enough to manage the rash and fever. NSAIDs are not effective in treating immune complex reactions. Plasmapheresis is not indicated in this situation.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has a hypersensitivity reaction to the sheep hyperimmune Fab antivenom. Glucocorticoids are the treatment for allergic reactions and antihistamines can also provide relief of symptoms. NSAIDs and plasmapheresis are not indicated in this situation.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has developed a serum sickness-like reaction, a type III hypersensitivity reaction, to the sheep hyperimmune Fab antivenom. Treatment involves tapering of glucocorticoids and antihistamines to relieve symptoms. NSAIDs are not effective in this type of reaction, and plasmapheresis is not indicated.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest that the patient has developed an allergic reaction to the antivenom, which can cause a rash, fever, and arthralgias. Treatment with glucocorticoids and antihistamines is the recommended approach. NSAIDs may help with the arthralgias but will not treat the rash, and plasmapheresis is not indicated in this situation.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The rash and symptoms suggest an allergic reaction to the antivenom, and treatment with glucocorticoid taper with antihistamines is recommended. NSAIDs are not effective for an allergic reaction, and plasmapheresis is not routinely used for this condition.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient developed an allergic reaction to the antivenom, which can cause serum sickness. Treatment includes steroids and antihistamines. NSAIDs will not be effective and plasmapheresis is not typically used for this condition.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest the patient developed a serum sickness-like reaction, which is an allergic reaction to foreign proteins like the snake venom immunoglobulins. The best treatment is glucocorticoid with antihistamines. NSAIDs and plasmapheresis are not appropriate treatments for this condition.
